TopicTitle: Another live stream of a rocket launch!

Articles.Content:
Hi!

This launch will consist of launching three carbon unit commonly known as "human" to the ISS.

One of these units will stay there for a full year, drinking 730 litre of his urine and sweat.

The stream started at 2h30pm (eastern daylight time), the launch will take place at 3:42pm.

You seem to have forgotten something...

[http://www.tsenki.com/en/broadcast/broadcast/](http://www.tsenki.com/en/broadcast/broadcast/)

[http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/](http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/)
T-20 minutes! One of the most experienced crews ever (in total, >1000 days in space), really exciting mission.
Hey was that really a tablet that they have on the soyuz?

CNN is also showing it live.

Having live captions on the NASATV livestream would be great.

EDIT: LAUNCH!

Went out of sight through the clouds pretty quick.
Soyuz is now flying free, with solar panels & KURS antenna deployed correctly.
Safely in orbit, nice ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) Docking in about 5 hours from now

And tune in for another launch in about 1 and a half hours (I think).

[http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/Launching_Galileo/Watch_Galileo_launch](http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/Launching_Galileo/Watch_Galileo_launch)

That was a pretty cool launch. I watched it on my phone in advisory secretily but then people looked at me weird when I yelled "LIFTOFF!!!" ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Y_byXe5srXs?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

Man, people are quick to post videos.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-27T20:17:50Z" title="03/27/2015 08:17  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 27, 2015</time> by Frida Space**

Missed it just an hour ago, clear night sky. Dangit! :facepalm:

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-27T20:44:18Z" title="03/27/2015 08:44  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 27, 2015</time> by Kulebron**

ESA live coverage just started [http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/Launching_Galileo/Watch_Galileo_launch](http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/Launching_Galileo/Watch_Galileo_launch)

- - - Updated - - -

T minus 10 minutes
First Fregat cutoff, now 3h15mins of coasting phase, then circularization burn into a 22,522 km, 55.04Ã‚Â° orbit.

> 
> CNN is also showing it live.
> Having live captions on the NASATV livestream would be great.
> 
> EDIT: LAUNCH!
> 
> Went out of sight through the clouds pretty quick.

ESA one did the same ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif)

- - - Updated - - -

PS what time (gmt) is Soyuz scheduled to dock with ISS?

> 
> ESA one did the same ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif)
> - - - Updated - - -
> 
> PS what time (gmt) is Soyuz scheduled to dock with ISS?

At 1:45 GMT+0. You can find the schedule at [http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/#](http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/#) at the botton of the page ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

It will unfortunately overlap with the second part of the Galileo mission, which begins at 1:30 GMT+0 :/

> 
> Hi!
> This launch will consist of launching three carbon unit commonly known as "human" to the ISS.
> 
> One of these units will stay there for a full year, drinking 730 litre of his urine and sweat.
> 
> The stream started at 2h30pm (eastern daylight time), the launch will take place at 3:42pm.

I hope these Carbon Units do well. Veegeer needs the information...

Again, people are *quick*.

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Dto3jT9aAQw?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

And both mission were **successful** ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) Gennady Padalka, Mikhail Korniyenko and Scott Kelly are safely aboard the ISS, and (from what I managed to gather) both Galileo satellites are on their intended orbits and working correctly.
